20576: Spite // Malice.author: DarthParallax
20576: Spite // Malice.text_parsed:
If both sides had been 2CMC, this would have been the ultimate Blue-Black spell. More iconic and devastating than Glimpse the Unthinkable. It would have made Lightning Helix look like a cheap trick. At 4CMC, nobody seriously wants to actually use it.

Are these effects that should cost the same? Maybe...maybe not, if you're putting them on the same card.

1UU and 1BB are my vote for what the best possible version of this card, looking at it from both sides of the tables it's being cast at, should cost. Still a little overcosted, to pay for the convenience, and a bit of extra inconvenience built in with the color density, but that would defintely get played. But hopefully the guy getting hit by it won't call it 'stupid/broken/they never should have made that.'

20576: Spite // Malice.author: dberry02
20576: Spite // Malice.text_parsed:
I started playing Magic when Odyssey first came out. I was playing a mono black deck with Spite//Malice in it. I was playing against my friend; both of us were pretty new at magic, so we had really bad decks. My friend smiles with confidence and says, "Drain Life. You lose." He said it so smugly. He didn't think my mono black deck could do anything - and frankly, neither did I...

But I had Spite//Malice in my hand... If only I had some way to counter his spell... Some way to add a blue... And that's when I noticed for the first time that I had a Bog Wreckage in play. The only reason it was in my deck was because I didn't have enough swamps. I sacced it for a blue and countered with Spite! That allowed me to stay alive and make a beautiful comeback to eventually win the game.

It was one of the first out-of-nowhere epic Magic plays that I have ever managed to pull off. I will never forget this card because of that.

20577: Pain // Suffering.author: Tevish_Szat
20577: Pain // Suffering.text_parsed: The funny thing is that Pain is a terribly beautiful small effect, and Suffering isn't really over-cost anymore: modern land destruction tends to cost 4 with an ability or 1CC, often with some sort of drawback.  If you're playing it for just one side... don't.  Use Stone Rain or Raven's Crime instead.  If, however, you can take advantage of either form of disruption, there is nothing wrong with this card.

20577: Pain // Suffering.author: Enelysios
20577: Pain // Suffering.text_parsed:
@Necrolysis It's not right to say its better, the two do different things. Desecrated Earth will get you card advantage, which is nice, but this can be dropped first turn for discard. Remember, you CANNOT cast both halves of a double card at once.

People who keep pointing out that there are better cards for either half are missing the point; being able to do either from one card is the advantage. Neither half on it's own should be a top tier card.

I would say this is a mediocre card only because discard and land destruction aren't things every deck needs. truthfully I don't think I have seen a deck that does a lot of both. If your deck DOES do both, then this is a great addition I suppose.

22317: Scouting Trek.author: Mode
22317: Scouting Trek.text_parsed:
Put all your basics on top, and then use Treasure Hunt to draw them.

This will allow you to flip Sasaya, Orochi Ascendant (and is possibly the only sane way to do so).
Then you can put all lands onto the battlefield with Manabond.
If you haven't gone nuts with landfall triggers at that point, make use of your insane amount of mana to win, e.g. by using Stroke of Genius or Helix Pinnacle. (And with Sasaya's Essence you can easily add various nonbasics such as fetchlands, too.)

22936: Capashen Unicorn.author: Mode
22936: Capashen Unicorn.text_parsed:
@nammertime: I agree that he can't say "Ronom Unicorn is strictly better" or even just "Ronom Unicorn is better".
But HairlessThoctar sure can say "Compare to Ronom Unicorn", since a comparison is about looking at similarities and differences. In fact, since these two cards have various things in common yet are still quite different, they do a great job for a comparison, don't you think? ;)

So say you need a unicorn in your deck for some reason.
If you want to cast it immediately and want it to be recyclable for some mana later in the game to disenchant something, take the Capashen Unicorn.
But as long as you don't worry about artifacts, probably have enough other two-drops you could play in your second turn like Hatching Plans for example, don't want to pay its mana cost later again to destroy something, and/or just don't want sissy unicorns but unicorns with bear power, take the Ronom Unicorn.

I admit, my comparison was somewhat biased :P
22936: Capashen Unicorn.text_posted:
@nammertime: I agree that he can't say [i]"[autocard]Ronom Unicorn[/autocard] is strictly better[/i]" or even just "[i]Ronom Unicorn is better[/i]".
But HairlessThoctar sure can say "[i]Compare to Ronom Unicorn[/i]", since a comparison is about looking at similarities [i][u]and[/u][/i] differences. In fact, since these two cards have various things in common yet are still quite different, they do a great job for a comparison, don't you think? ;)

So say you need a [1W] unicorn in your deck for some reason.
If you want to cast it immediately and want it to be recyclable for some mana later in the game to [autocard]disenchant[/autocard] something, take the [b]Capashen Unicorn[/b].
But as long as you don't worry about artifacts, probably have enough other two-drops you could play in your second turn like [autocard]Hatching Plans[/autocard] for example, don't want to pay its mana cost later again to destroy something, and/or just don't want sissy unicorns but unicorns with bear power, take the Ronom Unicorn.

I admit, my comparison was somewhat biased :P

22942: Shackles.text_posted: Question about this card: If I use a card to return the "Shackled" creature to my hand or sacrifice it to the graveyard, can the opponent get Shackles back by paying 1 Plane? Or does Shackles go to the GY?

22942: Shackles.author: UncreativeNameMaker

22948: Benalish Emissary.author: DarthParallax
22948: Benalish Emissary.text_parsed:
look more carefully at the card if you can find a copy- that's not a lightsaber (well duh), but it's not even a glowing rapier or anything that would look like a lightsaber close up.

the wizard is holding a SCROLL and there's a ray of light emanating from it.

there aren't a very many cards that I would recommend sniping online for actual common and uncommon prices (between .10 and .25 cents), bulk is usually the way to go.


This card isn't exactly unique but it's still pretty special and could be worth a whole quarter to the right Commander deck. White and Green actually infrequently Still get Land Destruction today, but usually it's either under the 'permanent' heading, or it's an Armageddon-effect.

This is precision-Land hunting at a sleek mana cost with a blocker attached. Very good answer to non-basics, of course, and I could definitely justify targeting a basic land against a 5-color deck. Most likely a 3-color Commander deck just isn't going to care if you shoot down its basics.

Exception: {R}{B}{W}-alignment has the weakest land and deck management of the ten Triple Colors, and with two enemy color pairs (Wedge) instead of two allied pairs (Shard), Land Destruction of any kind can be more effective than against a deck with access to Green, Blue, or better non-basics.

Given all the circumstances required to want this, I see Vault of the Archangel as being one of the top targets. =)

22949: Ruham Djinn.author: scumbling1
22949: Ruham Djinn.text_parsed:
"Remember, faisjdas, this was printed in the days before Bankslayer and such. Creatures used to be costed with the assumption that they wouldn't immediately be destroyed/exiled/sacrificed/etc., unlike now."

However, this was printed after creatures such as Mahamoti Djinn, Shivan Dragon and Serra Angel -- all creatures above the baseline of one-mana-per-+1/+1 / keyword ability. They weren't above printing creatures that were aggressively-costed back then. My guess is that since this cycle is uncommon, giving the creatures a drawback was a way to keep Limited (where they are solid cards) safe from an abundance of 5/5 monsters.

22956: Death or Glory.author: scumbling1
22956: Death or Glory.text_parsed: I do have to say I like the Urza's Saga "X or Y" cycle a lot better than the "Punisher" cycle of Odyssey cards (Browbeat, Blazing Salvo, ect). Yes, both cycles give your opponent a choice to make in how the cards play out, but it is a choice of how to divide the dividends; you get either reanimated creatures, or even more reanimated creatures, with Stand or Fall. The Punisher cycle tends to pair largely-unrelated effects, so you can't get any sort of consistency from the cards.

22956: Death or Glory.author: ProbablyThatGuy
22956: Death or Glory.text_parsed: While not on the same power level as the previously mentioned Debtor's Knell, or guaranteed to get you something you want, like say Rise from the Grave, this lends itself to EDH perfectly, at least to a deck that is creature heavy. EDH matches tend to be quite a bit longer, so you have ample opportunity to play all sorts of big nasty guys, or otherwise useful cards. Activate this when you have 10 creatures in the grave, easily attainable in longer games, and you basically give an opponent a "pick your poison" option. And beyond that, if you have an ally in a multiplayer game, you could always throw one single guy into a pile, and all the rest into the other, and have them let you bring back the large pile (provided it won't clearly win you the game). Also, this brings back a cluster of folks right away, so is not vulnerable to removal like the slower reanimators are.

22956: Death or Glory.author: Morgaledh
22956: Death or Glory.text_parsed:
To the Gate to Phyrexia rides the Knight Exemplar, her War Hawk perched on her wrist, her Attended Knight bearing a proud Capashen Standard, fluttering in the breeze as she surveys the Tainted Field before her. The Ring of Thune she wears glints in the Serene Sunset as she hefts her Loxodon Warhammer and shoulders her Angelic Armaments, gifts from Avacyn herself.

"Rally!" she cries to her Elite Vanguard. "Rally the Troops, and alert General Jarkeld that this Foul Presence will soon be Purged from the Living Lands!"

"Death or Glory!"

Don't know why this is rated so lowly (surely not just because of the art, as there are some fugly-ass cards on here that are rated higher), as it easy colour protection in certain decks. I use it in my Cromat voltron EDH deck. For two mana, with 5-colour creatures either on the field, or being attached with the aura, you get an amazing result. Not amazing in a vacuum, but really good if you use it well.

4/5

EDIT - Just a quick question, as I couldn't find it anywhere. If you control a colourless artifact, then this still doesn't give protection from colourless right, as they have no colour? So in a voltron deck, you can still pump up your creatures with equipment and wreck havoc.

22959: Teferi's Care.author: Ragamander
22959: Teferi's Care.text_parsed:
As of this comment:
Teferi's Care is rated at 1.375/5.000
Arenson's Aura (Ice Age) is rated at 2.344/5.000
Arenson's Aura (Fifth Ed.) is rated at 2.278/5.000

That's ridiculous. Sure, there's different art and different flavor text, but...really?

Teferi's Care/Arenson's Aura isn't even a bad card. It's tech against enchantments, and it's breakable tech to boot! Brilliant Halo makes it read ": Destroy target enchantment." That seems pretty good to me, and Rancor makes it even cheaper. Add the much more recent Enchanted Evening, and Teferi's Care/Arenson's Aura let's you nuke any permanent.

Furthermore, the second ability is not to be dismissed too quickly. There are a lot of powerful enchantments out there, and any way of repeatedly countering them can be useful. The relatively high mana cost is probably not a problem in slower formats like EDH/Commander and casual play.

There are also times where the ability to counter is necessary. What if there's a Mycosynth Lattice on the board and someone casts March of the Machines? It might be useful to counter that rather than eat an Armageddon, and Teferi's Care/Arenson's Aura let's you do it without needing a Counterspell in your hand.

At its absolute worst, it's a sorcery costing that destroys an enchantment if it doesn't get Stifled (okay, that is really bad). But at its best, it can wreck an opposing combo deck or perform a one-sided board wipe.

This should be at least 2.5/5, if not 3/5.

Yeah, when you pick bad ideas, it makes the card sound bad. But how about I cast Oblivion Ring, put the ETB trigger on the stack to exile your Umezawa's Jitte, then sacrifice my O-ring to destroy your Sigil of the Empty Throne. And I'd pay 5 to counter your Debtors' Knell any day, espcially for no card.

Think about better things to do with cards and you won't think they're all bad.

22961: Sunscape Master.author: Shiizu
22961: Sunscape Master.text_parsed:
Unsummon as activated ability?

This card is pretty good. Sure, you'll need a ton of land to make this guy work well, and hopefully some cards to exploit him, like anUnbender Tine or a Fatestitcher, or especially the Thousand-Year Elixir. But when you get this guy online, he's a behemoth.

+2/+2 to all your creatures is an amazing way to make combat really bad for your opponent. Especially if you can somehow untap him and do it multiple times... even your smallest guys will probably be too big to handle at that point.

Unsummoning even once per turn is certainly like stepping on the brakes for whatever annoying weenie deck that's coming your way.

Overall he's good, even if you can only manage to use one of his abilities.

22964: Atalya, Samite Master.author: endersblade
22964: Atalya, Samite Master.text_parsed:
I run it in a mono-white EDH deck currently. Not as the general, though. Her ability is really useful for draining off that last bit of mana before the start of your turn. Two life here, 4 life there, it all starts to add up. Once you get a large enough mana pool, she really becomes a threat, and people will waste removal on her, instead of something more important. Also, with Boon Reflection in play, you get more bang for your buck, as it were.

Outside of an EDH/multiplayer environment, I most certainly would use something else.

22967: Global Ruin.author: Shendran
22967: Global Ruin.text_parsed:
I run 3 of these in my 5-colour deck, and it works wonders! Yes, back then it was ok, since most played multicolour, but today it is even better as people either play monocolour, or rely on nonbasic lands. This has gone from being a simple bomb and a setback, to a nuke that tends to instantly win me the game, as I am left with my mana-base pretty much intact and then move onto assaulting them with big biggies.

Also, as mentioned, once you combine it with collective restraint things get even worse for you opponent, while the lowered cost of multicolour cards allow you to play almost anything for 5-6 mana. My opponents HATE this card, and they know that if I get one off, the game is pretty much over.

Another tip; This combined with Fertile ground or Groundskeeper allows you to pretty much ignore the effect, and potentially come out of a global ruin with 9 mana!

Easily one of the best land destruction cards ever created, especially if you can accelerate to get it off early, since most players will start with 2-3 lands in their hand, and then after that have to rely on one card each turn in order to rebuild their mana base.

22969: Divine Presence.author: Arachobia
22969: Divine Presence.text_parsed:
Arachobia's Name-Based Comments: Divine

Second highest rated 'Divine' card at time of writing. And I can see why.

I love continuous white damage reduction/prevention. I know for an opponent it can be a pain to deal with.

This one requires a bit more strategy to be usable. 3 damage directly is still a fair amount. It does add at least 2 more hits for your opponent to kill you. I think where this shine is in protecting creatures with 4 or more toughness indefinitely. White can play defensively, and a clump of defender creatures with 4 toughness and this in play will cause a real hassle for you opponent. Just make sure you can block all there creatures or gain at least 4 life a turn and you can keep alive for quite a while. I haven't used this card before, but now I see it I think I might just want to.

22971: Rout.author: dberry02
22971: Rout.text_parsed: In EDH: Rout > Wrath of God

22971: Rout.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
22971: Rout.text_parsed:
It's a card that is perhaps a bit slow in a duel, but Rout really shines in multiplayer. Getting up to 7 mana is certainly quite doable, and having instant-speed Wrath at your fingertips is comforting, for sure.

Flavourwise, WotC went in an interesting direction with the art on this card. We're seeing a castle burning in the background while Phyrexian flyers are chasing down fleeing refugees. In the context of the Invasion block, this makes sense - the initial invasion force absolutely smashed Benalia and other Dominarian nations. What that does mean, though, is that we're seeing a Phyrexian victory being depicted on a white card!

I do wonder, if they reprinted Rout in Scars block (now that the Phyrexians are back), whether they wouldn't rather show a rout in favour of a white-aligned faction in the art!
22971: Rout.text_posted:
It's a card that is perhaps a bit slow in a duel, but Rout really shines in multiplayer.  Getting up to 7 mana is certainly quite doable, and having instant-speed Wrath at your fingertips is comforting, for sure.  

Flavourwise, WotC went in an interesting direction with the art on this card.  We're seeing a castle burning in the background while Phyrexian flyers are chasing down fleeing refugees.  In the context of the Invasion block, this makes sense - the initial invasion force absolutely smashed Benalia and other Dominarian nations.  What that does mean, though, is that we're seeing a Phyrexian victory being depicted on a white card!  

I do wonder, if they reprinted Rout in Scars block (now that the Phyrexians are back), whether they wouldn't rather show a rout in favour of a white-aligned faction in the art!

22971: Rout.author: Cyberium
22971: Rout.text_parsed:
There are lock down cards that prevent spells from playing at sorcery speed, such as Opposition (taping your lands). Rout can be casted at instant speed which allows one to bypass that situation. Casting Wrath at your opponent's turn also free you up the mana for your next. You could also cast Rout in response to other instant spells, which allow more strategic options.

If nothing else, Rout is only one mana more expensive than Wrath of God, which can easily be a second board sweeper in your EDH deck without raising the bar too much.

22979: Dream Thrush.author: Ominick
22979: Dream Thrush.text_parsed:
This is a great little card for several reasons:

1. It's a flying blocker. I always welcome flying blockers. You don't want to block with this one because of its ability, but if you have to, you can still activate it before it dies.

2. You can screw up your opponent's lands. Make their land a color they aren't playing, or turn a Lotus Vale into a basic land. Used correctly, it can really slow an opponent down.

3. Continuing the theme of screwing up your opponent's lands, if you have a landwalker in your deck that can't hit your opponent, you can use Dream Thrush to make that possible.

4. If you have cards with Domain, you can use Dream Thrush to alter the numbers in your favor.

5. If you're playing multicolor, this can give you some much-needed flexibility early on. I put this in my five-color deck, because I know early in the game I won't have all colors yet. So if I'm stuck with an island and a swamp and I need to play Fog or Counterspell, having just one of these out makes either of those possible.

It's got nice artwork, too.

22984: Barrin's Unmaking.author: DarthParallax
22984: Barrin's Unmaking.text_parsed:
This is probably the best card of it's type, IF you are maximizing it-- and since all cards suffer the same weakness of 'sucks in the wrong deck' (EVEN Black Lotus- useless in Manaless Ichorid!), then I don't actually consider any drawback a 'true' drawback until you can prove there are no ways to play around it.

Here's how to play around Barrin's Unmaking when putting it in your deck: Make a deck with no colored permanents. Lo and behold! This card is BLUE, the best color for a low-permanent deck :)

When you target your opponent, even if they are playing a two-colored deck, you should still be able to turn this into a splashable Boomerang. Use in UW or UB control. It's not strictly better than Boomerang, but it's nearly as good, and strictly more Vorthos for mentioning a major character's name. :)

I give it 4 stars because when it's at it's best, it's really great, but it does need more thought put into it than Boomerang.

Final note: get a color-changing effect to target a LAND, and this suddenly looks much, much more powerful than Into the Roil!

22986: Exclude.author: Wanderer25
22986: Exclude.text_parsed:
Great card, I run it over Remove Soul in my casual deck. Invasion block was full of versions of other cards but with their cmc jacked up and a cantrip added. Blue got the best of them by far, I think. Compare this and Repulse to some of the others:
Recover - Raise Dead adds cantrip for 2, usable but still overpriced.

Restrain - Warning adds cantrip for 2, overpriced.

Smash - Shatter adds a cantrip for 1. Not actually too bad.

Reviving Dose -Healing Salve adds cantrip for 2 and no damage prevention option. Uninteresting. Compare to the much more versatile Renewed Faith.

Zap- Who knows? Shock? Meh. Useless.

Annihilate - Dark Banishing adds 1B for cantrip. Overpriced.

Tranquil Path - Tranquility adds 2 for cantrip. Overpriced.

Implode - Stone Rain adds 2 for cantrip. Overpriced..

Repulse and Exclude are the best of these because they deal with card advantage in the early game (bouncing and countering creatures), and remain cheap enough at 3cmc to be played then. The cantrip enhances the card advantage rather than being peripheral to the main function of the card, as it is with reanimation (recover), life gain (dose), or removal (Annihilate, Implode, etc). By the time I've reached the fifth turn the extra mana for a cantrip has become a hindrance with rather than a benefit.

So yeah, Blue definitely got the best of it here. Of course, these two have been sadly neglected for reprinting, while Smash, Recover, and Reviving Dose made it into 10th edition...

4.5/5

22987: Traveler's Cloak.author: dangersnaf
22987: Traveler's Cloak.text_parsed:
Land Type
Land subtypes are always a single word and are listed after a long dash: “Land — Locus, Land — Urza’s
Mine,” etc. Land subtypes are also called land types. Note that “basic,” “legendary,” and “nonbasic” aren’t land types. See rule 212.6, “Lands.” See also Basic Land Type.

The list of land types, updated through the Conflux set, is as follows:
Desert, Forest, Island, Lair, Locus, Mine, Mountain, Plains, Power-Plant, Swamp, Tower, Urza’s

Legendary is not a type.

Well, Gate is a type, yay!

22988: Opt.author: blurrymadness
22988: Opt.text_parsed:
Why do people keep saying "ponder" and such. This is an instant. If you know how to play blue at it's best, as it was meant to be played as it were, then you NEED instant speed. Instant speed means you leave your mana open for a counterspell of some kind, if they don't play something you want to counter, you just start card drawing. The only reason stuff like this can't make it in vintage is:
-Brainstorm
-"Free" counterspells (meaning no reason to leave mana open if you'd rather draw now => higher drawing power)

Instant speed makes or breaks draw cards. New kids on the block at sorcery speed are what it takes to make a sorcery speed one even compete. Note also that it does clear the way of up to two cards. Even if neither is what you needed this fixes the next two problems you may have had.

A year ago I got this and didn't know what I was doing so I stopped using it. Now I use it because it blows Ponder and such out of the water.

One of the best instant speed card draws that doesn't incur a card disadvantage. (Honestly, sometimes this is better than Brainstorm. Let the litany of curse words be hurled at me..)


Run this with Force Spikes (or similar one cost counters) and know what true power is.

I dont think people understand WHY this card is so good.

in combo situations its drawing you 5 deep each and every time because you are always able to get the combo piece you need out of the 5.

a lot of the time you get even more than that.

the card is actually broken, it will never see reprint its just too good.

the card creates situations for your opponent where unless they play at a very high level they are blown out, which isn't fair when dealing with a single card.

also it doesnt reward skill on the casting player either.

make it 4 cards and a sorcery and it would see standard play.

23000: Disrupt.text_parsed:
I guess people are completely ignoring how situational this card is.
Most of the time it's going to be in your hand, useless because the opponent didn't tap out to cast their instant or sorcery. The rare occasion it works, that's great. But I'd rather spend the 2 extra most of the time and have the more-useful Runeboggle (or better yet, Complicate).

edit : in tourney, you have to gamble a lot more and HOPE that when you keep the mana open, your opponent will cast an instant or sorcery and the spell works. But when they cast artifacts, creatures, planeswalkers, or enchantments, you have a wasted precious cardslot in your hand.

Personally, I can not stand having a card in my hand that is useless, especially if I kept a land open for it, so again I'll go with the more reliable counterspell cantrips.

Also interesting how the Weatherlight version of this card is almost a full point lower rated on here.
When it came out, I was one of the only people in my area that would give it a chance - everyone else dismissed it off-hand. Interesting how times and metagames have changed.....

This card works great in theory, and in practice too against RDW and the like.

However, it's the most annoying card in the world to have in your hand against an increasing number of decks which are entirely composed of permanents (or with maybe 4 instants or sorceries tossed in). 23001: Collective Restraint.author: JaxsonBateman
23001: Collective Restraint.text_parsed:
This card is a backbone of most of my "super-defensive" decks, and I'll often include some of the old or new basic-duals (that is, Bayou/Overgrown Tomb style) just go get it up to 5 mana.

5 mana is an insane commitment to make, and while many decks spare *some* thought for enchantment removal, they often won't put in enough to reliably draw it when they need it. WUG make good colors for enchantment-defense based play, combining this with Ghostly Prison, Propaganda and Sterling Grove (Greater Auramancy is ok, but there's no doubt that Sterling Grove is the better enchantment-shrouder). Throw in Enchanted Evening and you've given shroud to all your permanents and more or less can't be attacked.

It's just a pity that they can still attack planeswalkers. Jace v2 could win soooo many games easily behind this card!

23001: Collective Restraint.author: blurrymadness
23001: Collective Restraint.text_parsed:
I think my playgroup is just used to this sort of thing. I've had a Pendrill Mists + Propaganda + Winter Orb out before and while the game takes *forever* it could be managed. This is an annoying card but a good way to teach someone with a token or aggro deck that you need some other plans.

Obsidian Fireheart
Life loss
Direct damage (goblin grenade for example)
Permanent removal (ratchet bomb)
etc..

You don't need 4-of a card to eventually win a lock down; you just need your own control cards and your backup plan. This is a prime Duress target if I've ever seen one ;)

23003: Manipulate Fate.author: blurrymadness
23003: Manipulate Fate.text_parsed:
There is the concept of "Virtual Card Advantage" in which you compare not the cards or field position, but rather what cards can get them out of a situation that are left in their hand/deck. If you are against a deck that many cards will not help against, this helps you be card neutral while gaining virtual card advantage (by increasing the viability of your later draws. I'm misphrasing slightly given that i'm comparing "future virtual card advantage.")

Between this and filtering cards one can imagine a deck that has all of the answers and merely gets rid of the wrong answers as it goes.

Say you have a control deck that relies a bit on bouncing but you all the sudden run into a janky Hexproof/Shroud deck. You can filter three of those now useless draws out of the deck, get a new card, and hopefully be in a better position for the rest of the game. Similar can be said for conditional removal, kill spells against combo, anti-combo against aggro, etc.. and as mentioned, getting rid of lands when you know you'll have enough is quite handy.

23004: Metathran Aerostat.author: statiefreez
23004: Metathran Aerostat.text_parsed: I think people are forgetting that unlike Leyline of Anticipation and Vedalken Orrery, Metathran Aerostat gives you uncounterable creatures at instant speed. Plus, you can cheat him out with his own ability. Activate its ability with X = 4, then respond to the ability with another activation, where X is CMC of the creature you want on the board. Cheat out your creature, then use the X = 4 to play Metathran Aerostat. Since the Aerostat you're putting into play off the X = 4 activation is a different entity than the original Metathran Aerostat, it doesn't bounce itself back to your hand. In a multiplayer setting, Metathran Aerostat is actually better than Teferi, because Aerostat won't get you hated off the table for resolving it (unless you're about to win, in which case you're just another *** who thinks killing four people with an infinite combo makes the game more fun).

23005: Stormscape Master.author: cats_and_me
23005: Stormscape Master.text_parsed: Pretty good for control decks, but doesn't have a large enough impact on the board situation, and it takes a while before you really get something for your mana.. However, it allows you to counter spells targeting your creatures, and it allows you to counter spells targeting ~enemy~ creatures! :) You can even destroy auras by having creatures gain protection from the aura's color.. Such strange things are the reason why most cards only "protect" your own creatures, but this is a very interesting exception! :) This is the best combination of colors for creatures with tapping effects, because of Merieke Ri Berit, Royal Assassin, Mangara Of Corondor and blue tapping / untapping effects.. And Thousand-Year Elixir allows this creature to protect itself as soon as it enters play, you just have to have two mana sources for white mana..

23006: Blind Seer.author: DarthParallax
23006: Blind Seer.text_parsed:
Make Black Lotus look like a waste of mana? CHALLENGE ACCEPTED! >:D

It would be somewhat amusing if Nicolas Cage found Secret Codes on the back of the foils of this card that only characters related to the Egyptian God Monsters or Zorc could read that somehow turned this card into the most Busted Planeswalker of all time:

Urza, Broken Super Planeswalker {3}{5}{W}{W}{W}{U}{U}{U}{B}{B}{B}{R}{R}{R}{G}{G}{G} (CMC:50)

+5: Lands you control produce mana of any color this turn and Necropotence.
+10: Put a Blue Planeswalker token into play with "Starting: 3", "+1: Fateseal 1", "0: Brainstorm" and "-1: Unsummon"
-20: Search your library for a Planeswalker card, and put it on top of your library, then gain control of target Planeswalker.
-30: Put a colorless Artifact Planeswalker token into play with "Starting: 5", "+4: Exile target card from a player's hand", and "-3: Vindicate"
v
v
-150: a. Worldfire, then Restart the Game.
b. You gain control of all things exiled this way, then untap all your lands and after your next combat phase there is an additional combat phase followed by an additional main phase.
c. Creatures you control are indestructible and have hexproof and haste as long as you are not being beaten to death by your friends.
d. Worldfire Again, and Restart the Game.
e. Exile all Libraries, then shuffle all cards exiled this way into your library.
f. Punch a puppy in the face, then you gain an Emblem that has "I am an A$$hole" written all over it.
g. Then genesplice all your opponents into one Metathran-opponent, then draw twenty cards, then Worldfire Again.
h.Then gain 100 life, then Sharahazad.
i. Populate, then proliferate, then you may reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a spell. Spells you cast this turn have cascade and storm. Cast it without paying its mana cost, then do it all again.
j. Urza, Broken Super Planeswalker gains 150 loyalty and may use another loyalty ability this turn.
k. Urza, Broken Super Planeswalker becomes a 15/15 unexileable A$$hole creature with flying, double strike, and Protection from Everything until end of turn that has {0}: Take an extra turn after this one and Annihilator X, where X is the number of loyalty counters on him.
l. He's still a planeswalker.
m. As long as you are playing MAGIC in any game and control Urza, Broken Super Planeswalker in any subgame, you may put a copy of any Urza, Broken Super Planeswalker into play under your control in any other subgame on the stack. Activate THIS ability once per subgame. This doesn't mean all of them at once, it means you can add one more Urza, Broken Super Planeswalker copy to a subgame any time you are in a new subgame from the subgame you were in when you last used this ability as long as you control an Urza, Super Broken Planeswalker in the subgame you are in, who enjoys subgames.
^
^And that is what Urza's Ultimate would look like. :)

23007: Empress Galina.author: endersblade
23007: Empress Galina.text_parsed:
This card is a powerhouse in EDH. More people play legendary permanents in EDH than probably any other format. And that's not counting their generals!

I play this in a Merfolk EDH deck. I do have the common decency not to steal people's generals unless it actually serves a strategic purpose (like, keeping me alive lol). I don't do it just for the heck of it. I will, however, steal lands, enchantments, or any creatures as often as I can. I especially used to love, before it got banned in EDH, stealing people's emrakul, swinging at them with it, then sac'ing it to Altar of Dementia :-) Taught my play group not to drop that guy anymore.

As an EDH general, this is as evil as Tsabo Tavoc. In fact, even worse.

Mono-coloured generals are great when they're a good card themselves, because getting mana and colours for one colour is... well, very easy.

The added fact that it isn't too expensive (5 cmc general is really average), and the fact that it's effect doesn't end when she dies is just gravy.

"Oh, you've got Animar with 5 +1/+1 counters? How interesting..."

23011: Distorting Wake.author: humor_love
23011: Distorting Wake.text_parsed:
The only scenario in which Vacuumelt is better - or is at least cheaper per creature returned - is when one creature is being returned to its owner's hand (which sort of defeats the purpose of including either of these two cards in a deck). Distorting Wake is cheaper for two or more creatures. Rather than saying that Distorting Wake is "situationally better" than Vacuumelt, it seems more precise to say that Distorting Wake is "almost always better" than Vacuumelt.

As a card slot in a deck, in my mind Distorting Wake compares/contrasts well with Capsize (though I realize that the two cards operate at different paces and on different scales, their fundamental premises (i.e. returning creatures to their owners' hands) are quite similar if not identical - picture both of the cards cast with 6 mana) and (probably more so) with Evacuation (5 mana).

A major advantage this card has over Vacuumelt and Evacuation is that Distorting Wake returns target nonland permanents. Vacuumelt and Evacuation return only creatures. One of Evacuation's main upsides is that it doesn't target - hence the comparison to Wrath of God elsewhere in this discussion. Capsize returns any single target permanent - especially land cards. ;)

23012: Breaking Wave.author: A3Kitsune
23012: Breaking Wave.text_parsed: In one of MaRo's articles (Here's the Kicker, part of the Making Magic column), he talks about the development of certain Invasion cards. One bit of info he revealed, this card and the others of it's cycle were originaly supposed to have Kicker. The reason it was removed was during templating, it was realised that Kicker costs aren't paid until you play the spell. In other words, too late for it to allow a Sorcery to be played as an Instant. The ability had to be changed into something that isn't Kicker for it to work.
23012: Breaking Wave.text_posted: In one of MaRo's articles (Here's the Kicker, part of the Making Magic column), he talks about the development of certain Invasion cards. 23012: Breaking Wave.author: thought_jar
23012: Breaking Wave.text_parsed:
The rules for this seem a bit twisted to me, for these reasons (correct me if I am wrong because I guess I must be)

To cast a spell,These are the first two steps
1. Declare you are casting it (see point 1) and put it on the stack
2. Announce mode choice

To put it on the stack at instant speed would require having already decided to pay 2 more to cast it, but you can't decide to pay 2 more to cast it until step 2 (when it's already on the stack).

307.1. A player who has priority may cast a sorcery card from his or her hand during a main phase of
his or her turn when the stack is empty. Casting a sorcery as a spell uses the stack. (See rule 601,
“Casting Spells.”)

601.2b "...If the spell has alternative or additional costs that will be paid as it’s being cast such as
buyback or kicker costs (see rules 117.8 and 117.9), the player announces his or her intentions
to pay any or all of those costs (see rule 601.2e)..."

The way I'm reading the card seems to suggest that you pay for the card before casting it, which contradicts rule 601.2 (ordering of casting procedure).

  2. Announce mode choice

23015: Teferi's Response.author: yyukichigai
23015: Teferi's Response.text_parsed:
One of the earlier cards to allow you to counter an ability, following after Rust and Interdict. Unlike those spells, this one was very much focused with a specific threat in mind. Or as someone else put it, "destroy target Rishadan Port".

Aside from the reasons listed elsewhere, this is a good card to carry in decks where specific lands really help the deck function, e.g. Tolarian Academy et al, Swarmyard, and so on. It's always a good feeling when your opponent "innocently" targets one of your lands via Opposition, only to fail, lose the card, and watch you draw two cards to boot.

Also of note: this card targets the effect rather than the card causing it. This means it can selectively destroy permanents with shroud or hexproof, which is pretty neat.

23015: Teferi's Response.author: WhiteWizard42
23015: Teferi's Response.text_parsed:
JFM 2796 - "Am I missing something? Because all I see is Instant, "Draw two cards." Can't you just cast this and not counter anything?"

No, you can't cast a spell that targets unless you have a legal target to cast it on.

That said, it may have been printed as "Screw You, Rishadan Port", but it turned into "Nyah Nyah, Opposition" during the next Standard Metagame.

23020: Urborg Skeleton.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
23020: Urborg Skeleton.text_parsed: One of the best black super-blockers in the game. Nothing worthwhile is going to have trample until at least turn 4 anyway, so throw this pup down and use him to chump block the living hell out of everything coming your way. The kicker cost is that way so you have to spend all 4 mana from your turn one Dark Ritual in order to get out the 1/1 critter. But the point of the card isn't to kill stuff, it's to prevent damage from being dealt to you. This card makes Goblin Guide cry in uselessness. 5/5 For excellence in early game play and a late game mana dump when your Cabal Coffers is pumping out 20 useless mana. Oh, by the way youngin', the kicker cost being that high used to help when REAL magic was played with mana burn. It allowed you to effectively use CC and not have to worry about taking damage from it later since your Phyrexian Arena was already limiting your life expenditure.

23020: Urborg Skeleton.author: jonrds
23020: Urborg Skeleton.text_parsed:
Will-o-the-wisp: $1.67
Urborg Skeleton: $0.05
rimebound dead: $0.03 (but needs snow-covered swamps)
Snow-covered Swamp: $0.25 * 5 = $1.25

For that really, really budget deck, this is great. It still isn't bad, but there are better alternatives that aren't too expensive.

Notice how I ignored the kicker. You don't play this for the kicker. Its a nice topdecking addon, but not what you should be looking at.

23021: Plague Spitter.author: majinara
23021: Plague Spitter.text_parsed:
I love that dude, not only because of the art.
- Your opponent has weenies and you play this, then they are doomed. Either when this stays in play or when it dies.
- If unblocked it deals a nice 3 damage each turn to your opponents.
- If it's blocked it kills even 4 toughness creatures.
- When it blocks it still kills 3 toughness creatures.
- if you put any form of lifelink on him (best loxodon warhammer) he gains you tons of life just by sitting around, from the damage it deals to itself, each player and each other creature.
- and if you really need to clear the table, play a second of these little buggers. Then they destroy each other in the next turn, dealing a total of 4 damage to everything.

23024: Bog Initiate.author: jsttu

23024: Bog Initiate.author: humor_love
23024: Bog Initiate.text_parsed:
Fix {W}, {U}, {R}, or {1} to {B} without using Green. Powerful, very useful, and underrated at ~2.5 right now.

This is at least a 3-star card. Playing 2 or more colors rounds a deck out tremendously beyond the capabilities of a single-color deck, and that's what this card really helps you do. If you've played Skyshroud Elf, you see how this card is very powerful given its placement within the color pentad.

What's with the errata? I liked when it said "look at target player's hand" because then i could addle myself (to throw Iona or something like that into the graveyard) without revealing my hand.

Edit: I think I may have answered my own question; Addle probably requires the targeted player to reveal his/her hand in case it gets turned back on its caster with something like Misdirection or Redirect. In such an instance, Addle's original wording would facilitate cheating because the caster/target of Addle could claim he/she had no cards of the chosen color in hand without having to prove it.

It's not bad. -5/-5 in a domain deck for three mana. The casting cost is easy too, requiring only one colored mana. Enchantment means that it's just sorcery speed. If I'd build a casual domain deck, I'd surely add some of these.

23033: Hypnotic Cloud.author: Burningsickle
23033: Hypnotic Cloud.text_parsed:
@sir_dwar: I agree. Obviously all sorceries are better if made instants, but the slower speed is a balancing factor.

That said, this card honestly isn't likely to see a whole lot of yes. 1 discard for two mana, and not even randomized discard or distress is simply underwhelming. The majority of starting hands has 1 or 2 cards that don't belong in an early game hand, which is exactly what will be discarded by this.

By the Time you were to hit 6 mana in a black deck (assuming you don't have mana-ramp, something that is uncommon but possible in black), your opponent will almost certainly have less than 4 cards in his hand, and probably will only have 1 or 2 he is simply waiting to dump.

Although, decks that rely on frequent draws, Multiplayer matches where people are hesitant to summon things, or mana-ramp decks could make some use of this.

23036: Phyrexian Reaper.author: Cyberium
23036: Phyrexian Reaper.text_parsed:
According to its wording, it can technically destroy green creatures with Protection from Black. PoB means:

1) The creature cannot be damaged by a black source, 2) the creature cannot be targeted by a black source, and 3) the creature cannot be blocked by a black creature.

Reeper's ability doesn't violate any of the above, so it can kill PoB green creatures.

I wouldn't say it's terrible though.
You have the option to play it unkicked. Compare it to Riftwing Cloudskate, or Ogre Savant. A little better and a little worse than both; Savant has one more toughness but only bounces creatures, and only comes down for 5. Cloudskate has flying and suspend, but only attacks for 2.

Dismember? Who needs that? lol, SO glad I discovered this.

Dismember in a non-black deck costs the same life, for half the effect- with the upshot being it kills a small number more kinds of creatures, but targeting a whole less creature in the first place is a big deal.

In a black deck, I could almost see running Dismember anyway, because it can cost 1B and 2 life to kill one creature, and this is 1BB and 5 life to kill 2 creatures, and both of those deals sound the same to me. 23049: Nightscape Master.author: Aquillion
23049: Nightscape Master.text_parsed:
Reusable bouncing is really powerful, especially at such a low mana cost. Yes, this is expensive, but compare this to Temporal Adept, which is still considered a very powerful card -- it can bounce anything, has one less cmc, and is just one color, but it costs one more to use and doesn't have the damage option.

(And paying one less to bounce things does matter, because it's a power that becomes overwhelming if you can use it every turn, forcing your opponent to pay much more than you to keep their cards on the board.)

23050: Devouring Strossus.author: majinara
23050: Devouring Strossus.text_parsed:
I love that guy.
With 9 toughness he can't be killed by burn easily, and beeing black he is immune to lots of black removal. Not to mention that if something would destroy him you can still regenerate him, which doesn't even cost mana. Also, in case someone would steal him or whatever, you can make him munch up himself at any moment. :)
Costing only 8 mana while beeing 9/9 trample and flying is just great.

It's no tournament quality card, but I have him in quite a lot of multiplayer decks and he won me a good amount of games.

Yesterday I had him in play in some edh/commander game. Someone attacked me with a Keiga, the tide star. The strossus blocked, killed keiga, the guy chose stross with the steal-ability. So I used my cauldron of souls to give the strossus persist, had him eat up himself, he persisted back to play and the steal ability fizzled. I love this guy. :)

@ EvilCleavage: I'm 100% sure that it works that way. :) Your opponnent targets the Strossus with a spell or ability (removal, steal, bounce, whatever). Before it resolves, you gain priority. Then you sac the Strossus. Since the target of that spell or ability is gone, it will be countered on resolution.

23050: Devouring Strossus.author: GrimjawxRULES
23050: Devouring Strossus.text_parsed:
A beefed up Lord of the Pit, but without the drawback of losing life, and with an added regeneration ability... I love this card, but if you ask me, Lord of the Pit wins my vote for having a better artwork (Divine vs Demonic) and having more flavor. Also, with Lord of the Pit, you can chose to pay the 7 life - it doesn't make Lord of the Pit tap, which means that you'll be able to deal the final points of damage at the expense of your life total, should your not have any other creatures left.

Still, I wouldn't mind at all playing with both the Strossus and Lord of the Pit in the same deck. Each has its own advantages and weaknesses, the Strossus's weaknesses being its higher manacost and that you have to sacrifice it no matter what, should you not have any other creatures, and the Lord of the Pit's weaknesses being the lower power/toughness and no regeneration ability.

Which is best? Well, if we clash them against one another, surely the Strossus would win, but keep in mind that the Strossus takes longer to cast, and that the Lord of the Pit can use your life total to stay alive instead of sacrificing itself. But as Majinara points out, the ability to sacrifice itself can also be a bonus in certain situations...
23050: Devouring Strossus.text_posted:
A beefed up Lord of the Pit, but without the drawback of losing life, and with an added regeneration ability... I love this card, but if you ask me, Lord of the Pit wins my vote for having a better artwork (Divine vs Demonic) and having more flavor. Also, with Lord of the Pit, you can chose to pay the 7 life - it doesn't make Lord of the Pit tap, which means that you'll be able to deal the final points of damage at the expense of your life total, should your not have any other creatures left.

Still, I wouldn't mind at all playing with both the Strossus and Lord of the Pit in the same deck. Each has its own advantages and weaknesses, the Strossus's weaknesses being its higher manacost and that you have to sacrifice it no matter what, should you not have any other creatures, and the Lord of the Pit's weaknesses being the lower power/toughness and no regeneration ability.

Which is best? Well, if we clash them against one another, surely the Strossus would win, but keep in mind that the Strossus takes longer to cast, and that the Lord of the Pit can use your life total to stay alive instead of sacrificing itself. But as Majinara points out, the ability to sacrifice itself can also be a bonus in certain situations...

23052: Andradite Leech.author: mellishkimo7
23052: Andradite Leech.text_parsed: Actually this card is a lot better than anyone has apparently realized. Consider this- on your 4th or 5th turn you have played a pretty solid wall or defensive creature to defend yourself effectively and have accumulated 4 or 5 swamps. You lay down Andradite Leech and your opponent laughs hysterically at how idiotic you are because of its obvious drawback. Next turn you power up the leech a bit (NOT TOO MUCH!) and attack. Suddenly the opponent has a major quandary on their hands: toast the leech with a spell or otherwise destroy it with a blocker, or let the 3/3 or 4/4 leech through. This seems like an easy decision until you realize that if they kill it, now you can play spells just as easily as normal, and possibly have cooked something up in the time since playing the leech, OR they let the leech through and take the damage in order to keep you at a disadvantage when playing spells. In the end they will probably let it through at least once or twice before they realize that you've duped them and they'll kill it. GENIUS? YES.

23053: Marauding Knight.author: DacenOctavio
23053: Marauding Knight.text_parsed:
@ NARFNra:

You're mistaken in interpreting protection from white meaning that it can't be destroyed by white spells. Protection specifically means can't be targeted, enchanted, blocked, or damaged by anything with the named quality, in this case white. Wrath of God and Day of Judgement simply kill everything that isn't indestructible.

In the same vein, this is completely pimp-slapped by white if the player has a Runed Halo and names this card.

23054: Yawgmoth's Agenda.author: jfre81
23054: Yawgmoth's Agenda.text_parsed:
Run in and you could get another use of an exiled card with this and Pull from Eternity.
You would also be able to exile Yawgmoth's Agenda with Oblivion Ring when the drawback becomes inconvenient, then disenchant or sacrifice the Ring (Infernal Tribute can do this with card draw). You can then use the Ring repeatedly, because when it is sacrificed it goes into the graveyard because Yawgmoth's Agenda isn't on the battlefield until the Ring's gone. Cast the Ring out of the graveyard when you want to exile Agenda and play multiple spells in a turn. Since it leaves play, the one-per-turn limit gets lifted.

23057: Spreading Plague.author: The_Murderauder
23057: Spreading Plague.text_parsed:
Aside from the combo potential and interesting interactions this card has, it's also just plain good.

In EDH, when you likely have around 2-3 opponents, decks that share colors abound, and this stops people from wanting to play many creatures at all. When creatures do manage to come into play, they're likely to just get blown up by the next person's creatures before they get a chance to do anything. Meanwhile, you can sit around, drawing cards and building up a great mana base, holding on to all the removal you would have otherwise been using.

Lethal Vapors has the same effect on the game state. Try them together!
23057: Spreading Plague.text_posted:
Aside from the combo potential and interesting interactions this card has, it's also just plain [i]good[/i].

In EDH, when you likely have around 2-3 opponents, decks that share colors abound, and this stops people from wanting to play many creatures at all. When creatures [i]do[/i] manage to come into play, they're likely to just get blown up by the next person's creatures before they get a chance to do anything. Meanwhile, you can sit around, drawing cards and building up a great mana base, holding on to all the removal you would have otherwise been using.

[autocard]Lethal Vapors[/autocard] has the same effect on the game state. Try them together!

23058: Twilight's Call.author: Mode
23058: Twilight's Call.text_parsed:
About that "pay for instant speed"-Cycle (consisting of Rout,Breaking Wave, this, Ghitu Fire and Saproling Symbiosis):
They actually could have made these cards have kicker easily.
Make the Sorceries Instants instead, give them "Kicker " and simply add the restriction "Counter CARDNAME if the kicker cost wasn't payed to cast it."
Would make it kind of a reverse kicker, but use the kicker keyword. Back then during the Invasion cycle it wasn't that relevant, but if these were intended to be Kicker cards it would have been preferable to have them with this wording for future cards that interact with that ability, like Rumbling Aftershocks.
23058: Twilight's Call.text_posted:
About that "pay [2] for instant speed"-Cycle (consisting of [autocard]Rout[/autocard],[autocard]Breaking Wave[/autocard], this, [autocard]Ghitu Fire[/autocard] and [autocard]Saproling Symbiosis[/autocard]):
They actually could have made these cards have kicker easily.
Make the Sorceries Instants instead, give them "[i]Kicker [2][/i]" and simply add the restriction "[i]Counter CARDNAME if the kicker cost wasn't payed to cast it.[/i]"
Would make it kind of a reverse kicker, but use the kicker keyword. Back then during the Invasion cycle it wasn't that relevant, but if these were intended to be Kicker cards it would have been preferable to have them with this wording for future cards that interact with that ability, like [autocard]Rumbling Aftershocks[/autocard].

If you're calling this card stupid, you've clearly never played against any deck that uses tokens and/or hordes of cheap creatures. This thing will bring an elf deck to its knees for virtually no cost.

There are obviously better individual removers; this is obviously a headcount reducer, and a brutally effective one at that. You can always Doom Blade some poor bastard after that if you need to.

4/5

23059: Do or Die.author: A_Real_Travesty
23059: Do or Die.text_parsed:
Interesting synergy with Gutter Grime that you opponent probably wouldn't be expecting.

You: "So I play Do or Die."
Opponent: "It says you separate my creatures into-"
You: "No, no. I'm targeting myself."
Opponent: "What?"

23063: Kavu Aggressor.author: Kirbster

Okay, look. A 3/2 for 3 mana is decent in red, especially considering you shouldn't have been bothering to block anyway. That's the only requirement: 3 power for 3 mana. Not great, but usable. You're set.

Now, if you had seven lands out and draw this and have nothing else to do... what, are you going to not pay the kicker? Yes, it's overcosted, but it doesn't make the card worse. Having a kicker cost, any kind of kicker cost, is not an additional drawback. Something about having the option to pay too much seems to really just rub people the wrong way. It's an interesting psychological case....

23075: Zap.author: reapersaurus
23075: Zap.text_parsed:
As with Bandage and Carom, the rating for this shows that Magic players completely misunderstand cantrips.
Compare this to Divination or Counsel of the Soratami (or even Sign in Blood or even Think Twice - tournament cards).
3cc is pretty typical for 2 draws. At Sorcery speed. This is a 3cc instant that draws 1, and kills a creature. (You would only play this when sideboarding against decks with 1 toughness creatures - TONS of utility creatures have only 1).
An instant that regularly 1-for-zeroes the opponent should not be rated a 1.1

23075: Zap.author: N03y3D33R
23075: Zap.text_parsed:
Might look like trash now, but in a limited environment this kind of stuff was something you would be glad to see. Invasion was plagued by underwhelming creatures with huge kickers that didn't justify the cost. Finding spells, even underwhelming ones like this were usually better alternative to the common creatures.

I recall opening boosters for this set and being appalled by a six mana 2/3 with reach and actually choosing a six mana 6/6 Sea Serpent with islandhome instead. I would have been happy with a slightly overpriced instant speed red draw spell for three mana compared to some of the other cards I got.

I don't like the argument that this card is bad because it is not an instant. Every sorcery would be better if it were an instant, but sorcery is an important card type in magic.

23080: Skittish Kavu.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
23080: Skittish Kavu.text_parsed:
@NARFNra: I can see why you say that, but I disagree about it being balanced at 1 CMC. Although red has a lot of high-quality low-CMC creatures, one thing it has always conspicuously lacked is a colourshifted Grizzly Bears.

If you search for mono-red 2/2s with a CMC of 2, you'll find a largely underwhelming group of cards. There are a few gems (Stigma Lasher,Kargan Dragonlord,Blood Knight and Ember Hauler), but they all cost . Once you start considering creatures, you'll see that every one of them has some kind of drawback:

-many hate to block or be blocked
-a couple punish you if they die
-some will cost you later, if you want to keep them around

If you think of Skittish Kavu as just another member of a long line of 2/2s, he makes a lot more sense. Truthfully, in fact, I'd say that it's a lot easier to overcome this Kavu's drawback than it would be for many of the cards above. In some games, he actually WILL be a Grizzly Bears, and in the event that you are facing down or creatures, a red mage has many, many options for creature removal.

I definitely don't think that he would be balanced if he cost . Against a blue or white creature he'd be a Mons's Goblin Raiders, which is underwhelming anyway, but against any other deck he'd be a 2/2 for with no drawback at all, which is ridiculous. Even Goblin Guide has the potential to generate card advantage for your opponents, and I don't think anyone would say that he is weak!

23087: Urza's Rage.author: Cyberium
23087: Urza's Rage.text_parsed:
Banefire = cost 4 mana for 3 damage, sorcery speed, and cannot be countered/prevented at 6+ mana.

Urza's Rage = cost 3 mana for 3 damage, instant speed, cannot be countered, and cannot be prevented at 12 mana.

While Rage lacks variability in terms of how much damage you do or how much mana you spend, it's a solid card. If you have two Banefire in hand, you may be able to kill your opponent in two turns but it would leave you tapped out, whereas Urza's would allow you open mana to react should opponent plays something dangerous. Don't forget Urza's Rage can't be countered right from start.

Banefire for straight burn, but Urza's Rage is probably a better choice for counter-burn variant as a finisher.

23095: Ruby Leech.author: Mode
23095: Ruby Leech.text_parsed:
The biggest problem with the Leeches was that you wouldn't even get a considerably big body at the cost, but just a little advantage - that comes with a huge drawback.
Jade Leech was the only somewhat interesting exception here, but was made uninteresting again by the fact that it requires two green mana to cast - which is why Andradite Leech is ridiculous as well since its pump ability is highly conflicting with the drawback. And the cheap little white, blue and red ones are all jokes.

Aside from control-changing spells like Donate or Confusion in the Ranks, and color-changing cards like Painter's Servant, Alter Reality or Mind Bend this won't get really interesting even if you build around those Leeches.

These could have come with one more power and toughness to be interesting. All of them.
Then they'd actually become pretty choices for splashing colors.

But like that it's a lot easier to just run a monored deck and play something like Blood Knight instead.

23095: Ruby Leech.author: Enelysios
23095: Ruby Leech.text_parsed:
Bazaar Trader + Painter's Servant + Ruby Leech, if your opponent isn't playing than you just got them on lockdown. (If they are, substitute another leech.)

It's a three card combo yes, but each card only costs 2 mana, and it is mono-color. Plus you get the honor of defeating your opponent with ruby leech.

Without donating it though, the whole leech series are notable for how blandly bad they are. They aren't even build-arounds like Leveler or Sky Swallower, they are just utterly bad. Believe me, I have tried. The 2013 commanders could get better effects with the additional cost. That's as close to a combo as I have.

Another thing that you can do is cast something like Earthquake or Slagstorm and then cast Skizzik on your next turn.

23100: Tectonic Instability.author: Aaron_Forsythe
23100: Tectonic Instability.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #17, 10/19/10

I played three copies of this card in the sideboard of my mono-red aggro Standard deck at Worlds 2001. I don’t remember siding it in, and I certainly didn’t test sideboarded games back then, so I can’t really comment on how effective of a card it is. I’m guessing it wasn’t all that great, considering the only other instance I can find of someone using the card in constructed is my co-worker and former teammate Mike Turian, who played the exact same decklist I did at that very tournament. Mike made the Top 8; I did not.

Whether it actually was a good card, it appears to have been created to be one. In the R&D multiverse comments, a developer posed the question: “Is this too good of a control hoser?” No one answered him.

Tectonic Instability was made to hose control decks, specifically counterspell-heavy decks. Those decks thrive when they are making their land drops every turn, countering key spells and using instant card drawing when opportunities present themselves. With Instability in play, playing a land becomes a huge liability, as it will tap you out and leave you unable to counter stuff on your opponent’s turn, giving them a decent window to resolve threats.

If you’ve let your constructed environment drift too far towards countermagic being a default good strategy, then I guess hosers of this power level are fine to print. It’s certainly a heck of a lot more forgiving that Choke, a blunt instrument that has the ability to chase all blue-heavy decks out of an environment, not just counter-based ones. And at three mana, Tectonic Instability is certainly no guarantee to resolve.

What I dislike about it as a hoser is that it isn’t very straightforward. Sure, good players can quickly figure out what it’s for, but a low-level FNM player may never quite grasp the usefulness of the card, even if he is getting blown out by counterspells match after match. I like my counterspell hosers to say “(This / Your stuff) can’t be countered.” Everyone can figure that out and get excited about the prospect of “fighting back.”

I suppose the open-endedness of Tectonic Instability allows it to work with some other cards and against things other than counterspells, such as making sure your opponent is tapped out before trying a game-winning creature enhancement, but those seem quite marginal.

23100: Tectonic Instability.author: CatchoftheCentury
23100: Tectonic Instability.text_parsed:
@Aaron: I've been reading your comments on each card and there are a few that I might agree on, and surely because I'm reading as a player not as a designer/developer, but I just had to respond to this one.

The biggest thing that bothers me is that you mention how FNMers might not get it right away and what-not, but I think this is why the card is so good. It is subtle, it rewards players for thinking outside the box, to do a bit of research... Magic may be a game, but when you are looking to get ahead, sometimes actively looking for answers like this card and find it, you feel good. You found a way to stop those annoying decks. The sense of discovery is applicable here. Discovering that gem in the pile of dust, your saving grace. That also has a lot of bearing.

Wasn't one of the intentions of Magic to be a sort of adventure? To give the game a sense of discovery? This plays right into that. I love cards with subtleties like these and I know a lot of people do. I'm not saying to make every card not blatantly obvious, however, I'd rather say "wow, this can be used for this..." than your example of simplicity.

I think simplicity in the game is fine, yet oversimplifying everything will eventually a game of this breadth and depth become another stupid card game.

In fact, recently I discovered that you could use Kazuul, Tyrant of the Cliffs (a little better than Urabrask in other match-ups) to combat ExarchTwin. I mean, WOW.

Just sayin'

23100: Tectonic Instability.author: Cheza
23100: Tectonic Instability.text_parsed:
@ Aaron:
Don't forget that there are abilities that support this strategy, see: Branded Brawlers. So this card gets in-line with: Stoneshaker Shaman, Citadel of Pain, etc.

What it means to be "tapped out" is obvious for the most players, even for those @ FNM. And once you have taught them to wait to cast their instants until the very last moment, they understand the rest very soon. And the frustration to play against a counter-deck is a moment everyone will have to go through as long as this kind of spell exist.

So even if you've written a reminder on this card (that player can't use tapped lands on any other turn), you wouldn't have changed a thing. So for me, this card is quite perfect. The only thing I would change is the concept of when the mana pool is emptied or to put more effort into explaining this concept to new players.

The more complicated cards are great for playing around with, but the simple ones are for filling obvious holes.

23100: Tectonic Instability.author: Salient
23100: Tectonic Instability.text_parsed:
One of mono-red's stealth weapons (see also, Blood Moon).

It's really hard to appreciate this card's effect until you play it against a deck that relies heavily on fetchlands. Combo decks in particular are pretty impervious to Wasteland precisely because they sit on uncracked fetchlands, waiting to tutor up the dual lands they need until the turn they go off. If you use Wasteland to destroy their fetchland, they respond by cracking the fetchland; if you wait until they go off, they just tap their fetched Underground Seas for mana immediately. Wasteland: worthless vs. combo.

With an Instability in play, you can actually wasteland their fetchlands! They're screwed: either they let Instability tap the fetchland, in which case you Wasteland their now-unusable fetchland, or they use the fetchland "at instant speed" before Tectonic's ability resolves, in which class you Wasteland the dual land they go fetch.

Their only "safe" option is to fetch a basic land -- which is exactly what you want, because they'll make exactly the types of suboptimal "oh crap I should've gotten an Island instead" plays they were trying to avoid with the fetchland-heavy strategy. Wasteland: all-star status restored.

This card isn't in any Legacy decks' sideboards currently because (1) red doesn't have feasible acceleration to support and (2) red just doesn't have the support cards to build around a clever control trick -- Red Deck Wins has no room for subtlety, Aggro Loam has no room for disruption. But mono-black control should always be thinking about dropping MBC and splashing red specifically because of creative cards like this. In 98% of metagames, this won't help, but if you intuit the metagame at the right time...

23106: Kavu Titan.author: Falyxron
23106: Kavu Titan.text_parsed:
This card was actually what made me stop playing Magic for many years. When this card was printed, it came as a sort of confirmation to me that Wizards was making cards that they knew were overpowered, and only balancing this by making them rare. While it sounds workable in theory, in reality it just meant that in order to be good at the game, you needed to spend a lot of money.

My beef with the card aside, it is an excellent creature, and if you're making a green beatdown deck, I would highly recommend it. It's a good card to have in your hand at any point in the game, which is a boast not many other creatures can make.

My beef with the card aside, it is an excellent creature, and if you're making a green beatdown deck, I would highly recommend it.  It's a good card to have in your hand at any point in the game, which is a boast not many other creatures can make.

The key is to have enough people to play with who are interested in casual play and not just building $500 tournament decks that they got off the net. The other key is to make good use of what you have. 23106: Kavu Titan.author: Fanaticmogg
23106: Kavu Titan.text_parsed: Mark Rosewater once told a story about how, during playtesting, he was given a deck that used Grizzly Bears as a proxy for this. However, he didn't know that at first. When he found out, he began holding it back so that he could play it with kicker, and ended up winning fewer games. The lesson? Grizzly Bears is better than this, due to being worse than this... or something.

23106: Kavu Titan.author: Atali
23106: Kavu Titan.text_parsed:
@Fanaticmogg

The lesson isn't that grizzly bears is better than this, it's that you shouldn't hold out for the 5/5 trampler when you need the 2/2. When you have two mana and this in hand, cast it, when you have five mana, cast it kicked.

The point of a kicker like this is that Kavu Titan won't be a dead draw on turn 4 or later.

23106: Kavu Titan.author: Magnor_Criol
23106: Kavu Titan.text_parsed:
Atali's correct. He wasn't saying Grizzly Bears was better than this card. He was making a point about how giving the player too many choices and decisions can, design-wise, be quite bad. And on a gameplay scale, how you need to cast things as you need them, not hold on to them until they can't help you anymore. =p

As everyone else has said, this is just a great card. It's one of the few kicker cards that is aggressively-costed on both ends (2 for a 2/2 is good, 5 for a 5/5 trample is great).
23106: Kavu Titan.text_posted:

23106: Kavu Titan.author: scumbling1
23106: Kavu Titan.text_parsed:
Mark Rosewater tends to greatly underappreciate the intelligence of Magic players. He'd rather have a simpler card printed in Grizzly Bears than a more complicated one in case the player makes the mistake of playing it wrong and feeling bad about it.

I don't think you should coddle players. The people who appreciate the greater complexitiy are the players who will become more greatly invested in the game.

23106: Kavu Titan.author: kiseki
23106: Kavu Titan.text_parsed:
For those wondering, Maro's story about the card is here:
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/mr188

@Fanaticmogg, Atali, Magnor_Crio, scumbling1
The point of the story is that the grizzly bears are easier to play correctly, and that this card taught him to play aggressive decks more effectively.

Decisions are skill testing, but after a certain point they are just annoying. If you have to make a million decisions in a game, how many of them actually mattered? Imagine that you have the choice each turn to skip your draw phase. This choice adds no skill to the game. The decision to play Kavu Titan on the second turn or to hold it does add skill, and the correct play changes with your deck, the format and the metagame without being annoying.

23115: Tangle.author: Arvesius
23115: Tangle.text_parsed: I think Tangle is great.  In an aggro deck, you should be able to outrace your opponent (you nullify TWO entire attacks, and leave their guys tapped so yours can get in twice.  Just awesome).  Just the threat of possibly having this in hand can make opponents play too cautiously(no alpha strikes), so it can do something even if you don't draw it!  And of course, it keeps control/combo decks alive for another two turns.  Pretty versatile for 1G!

23115: Tangle.author: humor_love
23115: Tangle.text_parsed:
To Masamune:

The lockdown only lasts for one turn.

(It works like this, in a 1-on-1 game:

Your opponent attacks, you play Tangle, and there can be no combat damage.

You take your turn (perhaps sending your creatures past your opponent's tapped creatures).

Your opponent takes her turn, but during her untap step, is unable to untap those of her creatures which had attacked during her previous turn (when you had played Tangle).

You take your turn (perhaps sending your creatures past your opponent's tapped creatures once more).

Your opponent takes her turn, if she still has life points, and is able to untap her creatures which are no longer affected by the Tangle in discussion.)
23115: Tangle.text_posted:
To Masamune:

23122: Rooting Kavu.author: scumbling1
23122: Rooting Kavu.text_parsed:
But creatures in your graveyard are often a good thing.

"What if I popped a Relic of Progenitus?"

I'd just play more creatures from my deck. If I haven't won by the time that all my threats have been deposited in the grave, and I need to chance drawing into some more once they've been reshuffled into my library, I don't deserve to win.

Effects like this are bad unless you're running some sort of recursive tutor mechanism. Decks shouldn't need to use all their creatures twice to win (nor should they have the time to shuffle them all up and draw into them again to win).
23122: Rooting Kavu.text_posted:
But creatures in your graveyard are often a good thing.

[i]"What if I popped a Relic of Progenitus?"[/i]

I'd just play more creatures from my deck. If I haven't won by the time that all my threats have been deposited in the grave, and I need to chance drawing into some more once they've been reshuffled into my library, I don't deserve to win.

Effects like this are bad unless you're running some sort of recursive tutor mechanism. Decks shouldn't need to use all their creatures twice to win (nor should they have the time to shuffle them all up and draw into them again to win).

23122: Rooting Kavu.author: djflo
23122: Rooting Kavu.text_parsed:
The advantage of shuffling your graveyard into your library in any situation is that it makes it more likely you'll draw those cards. In a game against most decks, playing most decks, those cards are the ones you want to see again, or you wouldn't have used them, as opposed to the lands which have been lhinned out by you playing them.

However, all creatures is somewhat double edged, as you'll likely have smaller stuff like Birds or offensive weenies that are pretty much useless when top-decked which you wouldn't want to see. Overall though, this is a beneficial effect tacked onto a decently sized creature, 3.5 stars given when it was printed.

23136: Thornscape Master.author: majinara
23136: Thornscape Master.text_parsed:
The nice part is, that most cards say "target creature you control gains protection of a color of your choice". But this dude can give it to any creature. You can give an opponents creatures protection, to have aura's fall off or counter spells that would buff that creature or whatever. Or rescue your teammates creatures.
Shocking creatures is ok too.

23136: Thornscape Master.author: cats_and_me

23139: Blurred Mongoose.author: DoctorKenneth

@Nate: Why not use both? Then you can build yourself a Mongoose tribal deck. Mongoose, Mongoose, Mongoose.

Also, the Mongoose may have achieved light speed, according to the flavour text (it's gone warp!), but it's still slower than anything with Haste. Huh.

Anyway, while I tend to perfer Silhana Ledgewalker for the same cost - mostly for it's troll-shroud pumpability and tricksy near-unblockablity - "can't be countered" is a lovely line of text in it's own right. It almost looks like a color hoser without BEING a color hoser, which is just perfect. It's perhaps not a Great Sable Stag, but it's solid, and it gets so many bonus points for actually being (and remaining) a Mongoose.

23140: Jade Leech.author: Cyberium
23140: Jade Leech.text_parsed:
I agree with what some others had said, Jade Leech isn't bad at all.

1) Green has the highest potential of generating mana.
2) A 5/5 for four mana means that you would start the beating with or without any further spell casting.
3) It only affects green spells. In a multi-color deck, you have way more options than just green.

At the same time, it is true that Jade Leech isn't as good today as it used to be, but that's because of the power creeping, the card itself remain solid.

23143: Pulse of Llanowar.author: Morgrath
23143: Pulse of Llanowar.text_parsed: This card's not bad, but I think it's eclipsed by Prismatic Omen. Granted, Prismatic Omen leaves you open to any kind of basic landwalk, but given the general lack of landwalk around, it's worth the risk. The Omen also has excellent synergy with Domain, not only giving your basics every type but your non-basics as well. Tapping a Terramorphic Expanse for mana, and using that mana to cast a fully powered Domain spell when you only have 2 lands out is an incredibly rewarding feeling.

Prismatic Omen is typically a better card, but this is extremely useful in EDH as a back-up. One thing a majority of the other options miss out on is the variety of single-color mana; sometimes producing 5 of one single color is just as useful as one mana of each color.

I just wished it was worded better, even the oracle text is a bit vague. If it just stopped at "Instead" it would be much clearer, as the wording now still gives the impression that you can't choose the origional color (for example, your forests CAN still tap for green, but the wording makes it sound like it can't, and this confusion is obviously shared by people like Draugnor)
