24124: Dredge.author: Ladnarud
24124: Dredge.text_parsed:
It's excellent against things like Nettlevine Blight to get rid of an enchantment, or in response to things like Hideous End or Molten Rain to negate negative effects to you via your creatures or lands. Drawing a card helps to make up for the card disadvantage. There are also a few other uses i'm sure (Grave Pact, Deathgreeter, Abyssal Persecutor, etc.)

A very situational card, but useful in the right circumstances.

3/5

24124: Dredge.author: wxnbvq1
24124: Dredge.text_parsed:
First of all, you would never use this is constructed. If your deck was based around saccing creatures/permanents, say using carrion feeders and whatnot with rotlung reanimator to trigger bridge from below or grave pact, this card is redundant, as well as being worse than filler. As others have mentioned it can be used situationally as a cantrip while blocking a creature, but then again why not use other cards like carrion feeder, bloodthrone vampire or nantuko husk/vampire aristocrat, all cheap permanents which fulfil the same purpose while actually incurring a bonus.
2.5/5 for this card.

24124: Dredge.author: Salient
24124: Dredge.text_parsed:
Sack to cantrip? There's only two creatures that deserve that kind of abusive treatment: Stinkweed Imp and Golgari Thug. (I can't imagine a Dredge deck having a Golgari Grave-Troll in play but needing it as a dredger instead.)

In a good Dredge opening hand, this card is very nearly a Time Walk. Too bad it's complete junk in the graveyard (it doesn't even feed Ichorid!), which renders it unusably bad even for a hardcore mono-black Dredge deck -- a reasonable Flashback cost could have made this card a solid four-star wonder alongside Putrid Imp.

24124: Dredge.text_posted: I find it strange that this is rated so low (1.610) yet [autocard]Altar's Reap[/autocard] is currently rated just above 4. Yes, one extra mana/card makes them quite different, but still similar enough that I wouldn't expect such a discrepancy.

24124: Dredge.author: doombladez
24124: Dredge.text_parsed: @nemokara Normally cards such as this are what are called cantrips; you get some effect and then draw a card, thus maintaining card advantage. With Dredge however, all you get is sac a creature or land and then replace this card, thus all you get is a card that replaces Dredge in your hand, one less mana, and whatever you sac'ed. While there are times when you would want to sac something, there are better ways to do so than this. Altar's Reap on the other hand gives you card advantage with the sac option, which can be an extra good effect in the right deck. So whereas Dredge is a cantrip that doesn't necessarily have a real advantage, Altar's Reap at least gives you one more card than you had before you played it.  Thus the huge ratings difference.

25320: Wash Out.author: skew
25320: Wash Out.text_parsed:
Problem with this card in my opinion is, if you and both your opponent play multicolored decks, you won't remove all of his cards and posibly will have to remove yours. While you payed 4 mana, he will begin his next turn with all of his mana ready to throw his strongest permanents back at your head.

Also it's completely useless against artifact decks.

Still, returning not one or two but simply ALL permanents of one color is great cleaning and often fatal blow, so i give this card 3.5.

Compared to Upheaval, this one is less reliable, but in many situations better. While Upheaval is better to restart the battlefield, this one gives you chance to beat the living **** out of the other guy.

25320: Wash Out.author: Xycolian
25320: Wash Out.text_parsed:
The real beauty of this card is that it doesn't target a player, so you could remove all white cards from the board even if they're playing Leyline of sanctity or something similar.

This card behaves like a Day of Judgment concerning tokens.

Another amazing thing about this card is that, in multiplayer games, it can possibly affect more than one player depending upon which color you choose.

Also, this card combo's well with Jace's Archivist as it will force them to re-work a new board that will most likely be worse than the last. and depending on how many cards you returned, you will draw an additional 3~5 cards (or maybe even more).
So basically, you get to screw an enemies board, screw their previous strat they've been building up, and draw a good amount of cards all for 5 mana. Sounds good to me.

25363: Llanowar Elite.author: blurrymadness
25363: Llanowar Elite.text_parsed:
This card is fraggin awesome. Don't care about what a bunch of nubs rate it. It's a 1/1 trample, and that's an easy fix in green. Most trample comes on auras or somewhat spendy creatures. This guy DARES your opponent to block him and then you merely add one of the many many green instants that boosts size. If I didn't have a hatred for elves this guy would be a must.

Once you get a couple lords out this gets better, as you'll only have so many tramplers (depending on the deck) so a +4/+4 trample elf is a delicacy. This also ensures if the game carries on too long that it's not a "dead" card. You can make him a 6/6, not too shabby when you would've had a 1/1 on the same card..

If this card were blue, it'd be terrible. Red? Alright, but compared directly with suicide elementals (which are generally better.) White, terrible, the buffs aren't there. Black? Would also be excellent. (Buffs, lack of implicit trample, would've been a zombie.)

25363: Llanowar Elite.author: Kirbster
25363: Llanowar Elite.text_parsed:
I really like the idea. The "two extremes" kind of idea is cool and I'm glad they used it for one of the kicker creatures. That being said... I don't think hacking one or even two mana off the kicker cost would be outrageous. No, neither half of the average kicker card should be hyper-efficient to make up for the fact that it's versatile. Still, though....

for a 1/1 with a combat ability that probably won't come up isn't much but of course, that's not all the card is about. Let's say it's generally par for the course - he can still deal a couple early points of damage, then maybe chump-block something later on, neverminding any nice tribal interactions. If you draw him late in the game... paying for a 6/6 trampler is, again, solid but not outrageous - especially in green. You'd appreciate it in the late game even though more efficient fatties exist. But... nine mana? Now that's asking a lot. I realize he's a common, in the colour of mana ramp and just one half of a kicker card, but even in green a lot of decks don't stack up to nine mana. Only in decks dedicated to racking up mana, like elfball, can you rely on that regularly - in which case you'd rather just use something like Joraga Warcaller.

Long story short, Llanowar Elite is basically a Defiant Elf who makes for interesting conversation.

25837: Crosis's Attendant.author: DarthParallax
25837: Crosis's Attendant.text_parsed:
lol...wow. After reading the other 4...I wasn't expecting the comment thread to look like this :P xD

I'd say this is the best, not because of his Shellhead artwork, but because this color combination has no access to Green mana dorkiness, and is less likely than Esper to stoop to Artifact dorkiness.

(Remember- if you're thinking artifact dorkiness in the first place, there are loads better artifacts to consider. like Blightsteel Colossus. who happens to be creature type-Golem. yeah. 'Strictly better' doesn't even BEGIN to cover it, does it? :P o.O )

so, Grixis colors actually need this kind of ability more than the others do. even though you've already got all the Rituals between two colors, and there is probably some odd Blue mana ramper that's weaker than Mox Sapphire (so people won't complain when you play it), yet strong enough to be worth it (such a card is probably one of a kind).

All that said....everyone saying Composite Golem is way off track. We're looking to ramp into Dragons, right? we want stuff that costs less than actual Dragons. (unless you want to have enough mana for Dragon + X in one turn, like an extra aura to stick on the Dragon, or a live counterspell in hand)

Just purely focusing on 'GET. DRAGON. NOW.' like a Timmy, I'd recommend the Ravnica Signets. Same basic concept, and they compare favorably to being called Colored Sol Rings. Except printable.

But the Shellhead art IS nice. After all that ranting, I'm forced to admit this card is 5/5 :P

EDIT: I can't wait for Aaron Forsythe's 'Random Card Comment of the Day' to hit this guy. In 11,000 something days, it'll have to eventually! xD we need to make sure he covers this one before he clicks on any of the other members of the cycle- I think he skips cycle members of ones he's already covered.

25838: Darigaaz's Attendant.author: DarthParallax
25838: Darigaaz's Attendant.text_parsed:
thinking in terms of the age of this card, and the premise 'I'm going to ramp out Darigaaz' (a noble goal)
I'm thinkng:

Green has Birds of Paradise and Llanowar Elves, and gawd knows what other silly things they let you have all those years ago.

Black has Dark Ritual

and Red...did Red have anything that long ago?

We'll count Pyretic Ritual from the future for Red. (Seething Song makes too much Red Mana for 3-colored Darigaaz to get full benefit from, if we already have Dark Ritual in)

Red, Black, and Green together should be the ultra kings of Mana Fixing and Ramp, and are also the colors most hateful against artifacts. This is easily the least useful Attendant.

It's a shame. I actually like everything else about this entire cycle a heck of a lot, except for, you know, the actual text box. Change them to T: for CDE, no sacrifice, and they'd be awesome. :)

25840: Treva's Attendant.author: DarthParallax
25840: Treva's Attendant.text_parsed:
hm...the attendant's seem interesting. obviously the point they emphasize is that colorless and artifact ramp is probably going to be fairly widely available, whereas Colored Mana Fixing belongs entirely to either Artifacts that are too powerful, or Green.
So the Green Attendants all simply pale next to Birds of Paradise, which even today can stand tall and proud next to Lotus Cobra as just slightly less power for much more reliability and versatility.
BRG, RGW, GWU all can use Birds.
leaves WUB and UBR to prove that Attendants are worth using. WUB has artifact abusers...which it would rather use on more oppressive artifacts. Like Blightsteel Colossus.
This leaves Crosis' Attendant as the only one I care about.
Use him with Sol Ring, and Rakdos, Izzet, and Dimir Signets. :)


tavaritz: So you think Color Haxxing Matters on these, do you? Here:

Tinker- Urza's
Show and Tell- Urza's
Dream Halls- Stronghold
Mind's Desire- Scourge- Doesn't Count
Sneak Attack- Urza's
Through the Breach- Kamigawa- Doesn't Count
Fury of the Horde- Coldsnap- Doesn't Count
Survival of the Fittest- Exodus
Oath of Druids- Exodus
Exhume- Urza's- Best from this List (Def. Standard Legal at the time)
Reanimate- Tempest
Animate Dead- Alpha- Your Argument is Invalid.

I think I'll stop there for Black. Some of these cards got bannings. At the time the Attendants were printed, I'm pretty sure most of them were available. The only color that's weak at MASSIVELY CHEATING is White. (Red is kinda bad at it too. two of those are only from Modern era sets. Some of those were before Modern but after Invasion. Still, most of them are Urza or Tempest era cards people perfectly well could thought of, which were probably even Standard or Extended Legal at some point.

25930: Keldon Necropolis.author: majinara
25930: Keldon Necropolis.text_parsed:
- costs 6 mana to activate
- want's you to sac creatures

+ it's a land (not counterable)
+ repeatable direct damage to creatures or players is always great
+ it's damage from a land source. it's colorless, gets around protection and many other things

In short, I was nearly always happy when I had this in play, since it just gave me the option to kill something if I really need to. Once I had it in play with Rings of Brighthearth and Kjeldoran Autpost in an EDH deck. Sure, that requires a ton of mana, but it was in a very late game situation, and beeing there able to play two shocks each turn was very strong.

25976: Captain Sisay.author: Missile_Penguin
25976: Captain Sisay.text_parsed:
Captain of the Weatherlight, Sisay took over the job from Gerard Capashen when he abdicated his responsibility as a living part of Urza's Legacy.

However, she was captured by Volrath and taken to Rath, and the Weatherlight crew soon followed after to rescue their captain. The details of this occur during the Weatherlight expansion as well as the entire Tempest Block.

This card represents her not only as the leader of the Weatherlight crew, but also as a major general in the Coalition of Dominaria, the united armies against Yawgmoth and the Phyrexians. These events play out in Invasion Block.

Her ultimate fate is unknown, as she, along with Tahngarth, Squee, Orim, and Cho-Manno, used the Weatherlight to planeshift away from Dominaria as Gerard and Urza triggered the Apocalypse.
25976: Captain Sisay.text_posted:

This card represents her not only as the leader of the Weatherlight crew, but also as a major general in the Coalition of Dominaria, the united armies against Yawgmoth and the Phyrexians.  These events play out in Invasion Block.

25976: Captain Sisay.author: AmericanVigor
25976: Captain Sisay.text_parsed:
One of the master generals of EDH.

She is excellent for the astute ensemble of Johnny players that utilize the combo potential of green and white.

Her ability to tutor for legends not only increases your card advantage but also enables you to search for legendary lands (especially Gaea's Cradle and in some cases Serra's Sanctum) that can either allow you to acquire the mana you need to play some excellent cards in your hand and/or significantly increase your mana advantage.

25977: Hanna, Ship's Navigator.author: Elaedyn
25977: Hanna, Ship's Navigator.text_parsed:
Dear Wizards,
I like so many others who have been playing the game since its earliest days have developed a love for your product--your ingenuity has kept the game fresh for many years and we greatly appreciate it. Every once in a while you give us old timers a nice throw back, something to look at with new eyes and appreciate with a new perspective.

When you commissioned Terese Nielson to come out and re-work everyone's favorite girl next door, you gave us a new way to see one of our favorite characters. Now, I--we--come to you and ask you to give her (and her artist) yet another way to appreciate hanna in the form of a card with her new art.

Please reprint hanna in some sort of a commander's block...we miss her.

Yours,
The hanna players of the world
http://shop.tnielsen.com/images/PTHannaShipsNavigator16x20.jpg

26299: Plains.author: CorkBulb
26299: Plains.text_parsed:
This is my favorite plains art in the entire game. I love the feel of it. It feels like a hot, groggy afternoon where me and my fellow soldiers are preparing for battle. Fits great in a knight/soldier deck for that reason. I love the flat, dull colors, giving it color but without making it flashy or bright. I love lands that set a feel for the weather and the time of day. The layout is also nice, a downhill view of a vast, flat, grassy field with scattered rocks and the tree in the distance is awesome. Very realistic too! I specifically went out of my way to buy extra of these!

5/5 LOVE IT

26302: Island.author: Phantom_of_the_FNM
26302: Island.text_parsed:
w00t, first comment again.
Reasons why this card is borken as hell:
1, It defines block, standard, extended, legacy, and in some cases even vintage.
2. It's near-ubiquitous, even more so than skullclamp.
3. Every deck either runs them or runs a plan to beat them, and the decks in the first category are ususally better.
4. It's at least as common as, if not more common than, any basic lands in the format, when measured by how many copies are in each tournament.
I think this is cause for banning, personally. It's just that simple.

2. It's near-ubiquitous, even more so than skullclamp. 
3. Every deck either runs them or runs a plan to beat them, and the decks in the first category are ususally better. 
4. It's at least as common as, if not more common than, any basic lands in the format, when measured by how many copies are in each tournament. 
I think this is cause for banning, personally. It's just that simple.

26372: Phyrexian Infiltrator.author: Mode
26372: Phyrexian Infiltrator.text_parsed:
I don't know who downrated Chrisawr, he's right:

Activate the Minion's ability the first time and choose the card that is to be donated.
Now you activate it a second time and target an opponent's creature.
If nobody wants to respond anymore, the stack gets emptied:
You exchange control with the Minion and your opponent's crea.
Then the other exchange resolves, which gives you back the Infiltrator and leaves your opponent with the donated card.

Therefore it's effectively like Donate restricted to creatures with Control Magic included for each.
With Avarice Totem you can do this with any permanent for .
26372: Phyrexian Infiltrator.text_posted:
I don't know who downrated Chrisawr, he's right:

Activate the Minion's ability the first time and choose the card that is to be donated.
Now you activate it a second time and target an opponent's creature.
If nobody wants to respond anymore, the stack gets emptied:
You exchange control with the Minion and your opponent's crea.
Then the other exchange resolves, which gives you back the Infiltrator and leaves your opponent with the donated card.

Therefore it's effectively like [autocard]Donate[/autocard] restricted to creatures with [autocard]Control Magic[/autocard] included for [4UUUU] each.
With [autocard]Avarice Totem[/autocard] you can do this with any permanent for [10].

Wait, so a source's ability will follow the source to new owners while it's on the stack, if control of the source is changed before resolution?

Opponent: Myr Incubator. I put out 20 artifacts and pay 20 for Sludge Strider. You lose 20 life. I win.

You: I Infiltrator your Strider. I win.

I know that you pay the 1 mana on resolution and that this wouldn't work, and even if it did it's a ridiculously unlikely scenario :P. Someone help me out. Show me at situation that might be at least plausible.

26389: Stand or Fall.author: GrimjawxRULES
26389: Stand or Fall.text_parsed:
"Whenever you attack a player with a creature, half of that player's creatures can't block this turn". That's quite good if I must say so myself. It's not worded for multiplayer, but if you attack multiple players as once I assume you'll be splitting each of the defending players' creatures up in two piles, one of which won't be able to block.

It's a cool "do or die" kind of card in the sense that, if you attack with an overwhelming force, you can just leave one pile empty and ask your opponent to block with everything or lose on the spot. Disabling half of your opponent's creatures can also be a cool way of getting through with additional attackers and maybe even get lethal if you've got enough power on the battlefield.

26416: Quirion Sentinel.author: Fanaticmogg
26416: Quirion Sentinel.text_parsed:
Nomadic Elf beats it as a 2-drop body, and also as a mana-filterer since you can drop it before you need the mana filtering and it's re-useable. The Sentinel is better if you want to drop a lot of guys quickly, since it's essentially a 1-drop once you have access to two mana.

Both of them are 2-power dudes for 2, though, so an agressive limited deck would be happy to have either.
